title: Christmas dinner shopping guide sparks fierce debate about roast potatoes
text:

When it comes to Christmas, undoubtedly one of the best parts of the festive season is the feast.

Christmas dinner is a pretty big deal and for many foodies out there, you've simply got to have it with all the trimmings.

Shopping for the occasion can prove pretty stressful, so BBC Good Food Magazine came up with a handy little guide for how much to buy.

But some people took issue with the amount of ingredients they listed per person - and were especially angry over the recommended number of roast potatoes.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: Getty Images)

A photo of the guide was shared on Twitter by a user named Alice Pope.

Alice didn't agree with the guide's suggestion of purchasing one potato (or two small ones) per person.

She said: "I love BBC Good Food magazine but this is just all kinds of wrong, imagine a Christmas with one roast potato each."

Her tweet went viral, garnering 3,700 likes and being retweeted hundreds of times.

Many people agreed with her post, arguing that many more potatoes were needed and some also had issue with the amount of gravy listed - which was 100ml per person.

One person said: "I'd lose my s*** if I was served just one roast potato regardless of how many times it has been cut. I rely on the cold roastie leftovers on Boxing day to get me out of my wine-flu."

Another commented: "Hang on a minute... that roast potato/parsnip/sprout ratio is ALL wrong... and where ARE the pigs in blankets! I made 72 last year! (There were seven of us)."

A third added: "Actually a food crime. It’s a five roast potato minimum, with the option to have at least two/three more from the ‘extras’ bowl. And no one I know wants one whole parsnip to themselves!"

Someone else wrote: "100ml of gravy????? Madness. I need double that."

The BBC Good Food Twitter account later responded to Alice's tweet, with a drawing clarifying what they meant by "one" potato.

They said: "There's been some heated Christmas dinner debate today, so here are our workings.

"Rest assured there are plenty of us in the Good Food offices with giant festive appetites who'd up the quantities too (particularly the gravy). We love how passionate you all are about the potatoes!"

The drawing, titled Turkey Dinner Maths, shows how "one potato" didn't mean one roastie, but one whole potato cut into four pieces.

All four of the pieces were intended for one person to consume. Similarly if a person chose to use two smaller potatoes, these would be cut in half, to also generate four roast potatoes per person.

Phew!
description: A Twitter user started a strange debate after sharing a Christmas dinner shopping guide she'd found
